titleInfo.title: Letter from Francis Palms to Henrietta Lauzin, 1864 Aug. 21

mods.note: Francis Palms (1837-1904) enlisted as a private in the Confederate Army on May 23, 1861, at Camp Moore, Louisiana. He was assigned to Co. F of the Delta Rifles, which was part of the 4th Louisiana Infantry. Following the war, he returned to his birthplace of Detroit, Michigan, where he helped to manage his father's many interests. Mr. Palms was married three times, and, with his second wife, Miss C.F. Pellerin, had seven children. Henrietta Lauzin (b.1842) was the daughter of Dr. Jean Lauzin and Leocadie Teetzman and the great-great-granddaughter of Antonio de Gras.
mods.abstract: Francis Palms, 'Starvation Hollow, Near Alexandria, Louisiana', writes to Henrietta Lauzin, Honey Suckle Grove, West Baton Rouge, to inform her of his recent travels, including his time in the Capital, , possibly referring to Shreveport, which was the capital of Confederate Louisiana at this time. In reference to his time in the Capital he states, 'I never became so tired of a place in my life- the fare was meager and the prices exorbitant $20 per day- fruits were in abundance- melons were plentiful and in consequence I was never melon-choly.' He then recounts the last eight letters Henrietta had sent to him and comments on their contents before closing.
